issue.title: passing logger methods to a function (2)
issue.body:
I cannot come up with a solution to extract pino's logging methods.
I found a few issues here, discussing this one, but I cannot successfully bind `this`.

**Example 1**: using a single method:

```js
const logger = pino();
const info = logger.info
logger.info.bind(logger)
info('test')
```
Error:
```
/home/runner/PinoBind/node_modules/pino/lib/tools.js:68
      if (typeof this[msgPrefixSym] === 'string' && msg !== undefined && msg !== null) {
                     ^
TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'Symbol(pino.msgPrefix)')
    at LOG (/home/runner/PinoBind/node_modules/pino/lib/tools.js:68:22)
```
Sandbox: https://replit.com/@OnkelTem/PinoBind#index.js

**Example 2**: using  an object with methods:

```js
const logger = pino();
const methods = {
  info: logger.info
}
logger.info.bind(logger)
methods.info('test')
```
Error:
```
/home/runner/PinoBind/node_modules/pino/lib/tools.js:71
      this[writeSym](null, format(msg, n, this[formatOptsSym]), level)
                    ^

TypeError: this[writeSym] is not a function
    at Object.LOG [as info] (/home/runner/PinoBind/node_modules/pino/lib/tools.js:71:21)
```
Sandbox: https://replit.com/@OnkelTem/PinoBind#index2.js

comment.body:
@jsumners Ah, I was answering to myself at the same time.

Thanks!

issue.title: passing logger methods to a function (2)
issue.body:
I cannot come up with a solution to extract pino's logging methods.
I found a few issues here, discussing this one, but I cannot successfully bind `this`.

**Example 1**: using a single method:

```js
const logger = pino();
const info = logger.info
logger.info.bind(logger)
info('test')
```
Error:
```
/home/runner/PinoBind/node_modules/pino/lib/tools.js:68
      if (typeof this[msgPrefixSym] === 'string' && msg !== undefined && msg !== null) {
                     ^
TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'Symbol(pino.msgPrefix)')
    at LOG (/home/runner/PinoBind/node_modules/pino/lib/tools.js:68:22)
```
Sandbox: https://replit.com/@OnkelTem/PinoBind#index.js

**Example 2**: using  an object with methods:

```js
const logger = pino();
const methods = {
  info: logger.info
}
logger.info.bind(logger)
methods.info('test')
```
Error:
```
/home/runner/PinoBind/node_modules/pino/lib/tools.js:71
      this[writeSym](null, format(msg, n, this[formatOptsSym]), level)
                    ^

TypeError: this[writeSym] is not a function
    at Object.LOG [as info] (/home/runner/PinoBind/node_modules/pino/lib/tools.js:71:21)
```
Sandbox: https://replit.com/@OnkelTem/PinoBind#index2.js

comment.body:
Answering to myself.
`bind()` isn't mutating, it returns a new thing.

So the correct variants are:

```js
const logger = pino();
const info = logger.info
logger.info.bind(logger)
info('test')
```

```js
const logger = pino();
const methods = {
  info: logger.info.bind(logger)
}
methods.info('test')
```

Sandbox: https://replit.com/@OnkelTem/PinoBind2

Surprisingly, this was overlooked in previous answers.

comment.body:
```js
const logger = pino();
const info = logger.info
logger.info.bind(logger)
info('test')
```

You have assigned the bound function to nothing and then used the unbound function to log the string `'test'`.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Function/bind

issue.title: [mergingObject] under custom property
Log formatting, file stream, request parameter logging
issue.body:
Does this log to file stream, `/var/log/myapp/log-*`, for instance?
Does this capture various request parameters like the user, geo info, etc?
How to do that?

issue.title: Using a transport to transform logs and then write to a custom stream

comment.body:
> Thank you for writing it out, but I don't believe that really solves what I was asking for. How can we implement the "write" function inside the worker thread if the worker thread has no idea what to write to?

You pass the path you want to write to as an option. 

> I'm currently looking at this code from pino-pretty where they either take in a destination or it will write to standard out (essentially what I'm trying to do). But how does line 226 work?

That option only works if passed programmatically and not via the transport system, e.g. if you want to build your own transport that uses pino-pretty.

issue.title: How to use this with React.JS/Next.JS, preferable with Node HTTP2 server?
issue.body: Recommended in https://nextjs.org/docs/pages/building-your-application/deploying/production-checklist#logging but I don't see how to use this with React.JS / Next.JS, preferably using Node HTTP2 server?

issue.title: How to use this with React.JS/Next.JS, preferable with Node HTTP2 server?
issue.body: Recommended in https://nextjs.org/docs/pages/building-your-application/deploying/production-checklist#logging but I don't see how to use this with React.JS / Next.JS, preferably using Node HTTP2 server?

comment.body:
You can find a not up to date example of pino+next.js at https://github.com/pinojs/pino-nextjs-example.
This does not include http/2, ask the Vercel team.

issue.title: Using a transport to transform logs and then write to a custom stream

comment.body:
Thank you for writing it out, but I don't believe that really solves what I was asking for. How can we implement the "write" function inside the worker thread if the worker thread has no idea what to write to?

https://github.com/pinojs/pino-pretty/blob/fa386a964cce7d7c5cbeb4ce5bb8d28785001acd/index.js#L212-L246

I'm currently looking at this code from pino-pretty where they either take in a destination or it will write to standard out (essentially what I'm trying to do). But how does line 226 work? It is essentially saying you can pass in an object that looks like 
`destination = { write: some_custom_function} ` and it pipe the data to that destination. But you are saying otherwise, that we cannot transfer the write function to the worker thread. A little bit of confusion there
This pull request has been automatically locked since there has not been any recent activity after it was closed. Please open a new issue for related bugs.
